awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: Standard: Institutions in Student Organizations Cultivating Cultures of Ethical Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent studies demonstrate that extracurricular student activities can play an important role in the ethical development of students; however, it is not known which specific kinds of activities are most effective and why. This award supports a research project that proposes to address this question by identifying engineering student organizations, as well as institutional mechanisms within these student organizations, that are effective in cultivating ethical behavior. It will also test the effectiveness of informal practices outside of the classroom in four student organizations. The results of this research will contribute to the increasing scholarship in engineering education which emphasizes ethical concerns, the importance of social justice, educating globally competent engineers and critical thinking by focusing on contexts outside of the classroom that contribute to cultivating ethical cultures in the field of engineering. They will also serve to create a community of practice with the goal of increasing the visibility of ethical engineering and knowledge sharing among scholars in the field of ethical STEM.

This project investigates the role that different student organizations play in cultivating ethical behavior of engineering student in the U.S. and to identify the precise institutional mechanisms within those organizations that foster ethical behavior. Research shows that students are typically less interested in understanding the ethical implications of their work at the end of their studies than they were at the beginning. This gap between instruction and application indicates a continued need for research to identify factors that are effective in cultivating a culture of ethical STEM and promoting an awareness and understanding of ethics among engineering students. The results from the proposed research will directly affect student organizations within the studied institutions and beyond. This study will involve a diversity of key players in these organizations including leadership, mentors, and members to open discussion regarding improving engineering ethics behavior. The project will also test the efficacy of interventions and create a set of guidelines for student organizations. This research promises to educate ethical engineers within and beyond the university, and it is expected to have positive impacts on the people and communities that are affected by engineering projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Engineering students in the U.S. commonly receive instruction concerning the professional Code of Ethics for Engineers to which they will be required to adhere once they enter the field. Yet, research reveals that many students fail to recognize and analyze real ethical challenges as they arise in engineering contexts. Research shows that students are typically less interested in understanding the ethical implications of their work at the end of their studies than they were at the beginning. This gap between instruction and application indicates a continued need for research to identify effective factors cultivating a culture of ethical STEM and promoting an awareness and understanding of ethics amongst engineering students. More specifically, while recent studies demonstrate that extracurricular student activities can play an important role in the ethical development of students, it is not known which specific kinds of activities are most effective and why. This research project sought to investigate the role that different student organizations play in cultivating ethical behavior and to identify the institutional mechanisms within those organizations that foster ethical behavior. This research responds and contributes to the increasing scholarship in engineering education which emphasizes ethical concerns, the importance of social justice, educating globally competent engineers and critical thinking. 

 

This study investigated students' moral sensitivity by identifying the ethical issues to which they are most sensitive and the elements that influence moral sensitivity.The study discovered relationships between moral sensitivity and the institutional settings of the university as well as the student organizations in which students engaged. The findings show approaches to cultivate engineering students' moral sensitivity through academic instruction and extracurricular activities. For instance, one study evaluated students’ moral sensitivity by using a natural disaster that provided a useful context to evaluate moral sensitivity due to the complex effects of such a crisis on engineered, natural, and social systems. Students were primarily sensitive to ethical issues connected to socioeconomic inequality, while they also recognized the importance of climate change, infrastructure, disaster preparation, and corporate/government responsibilities. The study found the importance of institutions' efforts to cultivate ethical cultures in order to encourage students to learn about ethical issues. It underscores better institutionally related contexts by integrating classroom learning and extracurricular activities to improve students' moral sensitivity. Student organizations, in particular, can provide a place for students to address ethical issues and improve moral awareness. 

 

Our team was able to explore the culture of disengagement in engineering education. The COVID-19 pandemic provided an opportunity to evaluate changes in engineers’ engagement with issues of microethics and macroethics, showing that engineering students engaged mostly with individual and professional ethics in their studies and engaged very little with social ethics. Further, during the pandemic, we explored an engineer’s perceived role in the COVID-19 pandemic response.  Responses from women focused more on macroethics as compared to responses from men. There was also a difference in responses between the universities surveyed, capturing that institutional differences impact students’ macroethical development. In another framing, engineering ethics can be divided into three spheres: technical, professional, and social. We explored the extent to which engineering students engage with each sphere of engineering ethics by examining how engineering students understand their roles in addressing the pandemic and its implications. Results suggest that there was low engagement with both social ethics and professional ethics among respondents, while there was higher engagement with technical ethics. Despite the potential for the pandemic to encourage engagement with all three spheres of ethics, there continues to be low engagement with ethics beyond the technical sphere.  

 

We also investigated on-campus engineering student organizations as a means of promoting ethical development. Our results suggested that certain organizational characteristics were associated with students’ ethical development such as having sociopolitical events and professional engineering events as well as having outreach activities supporting social movements. However, engineering student organizations having formal competitions tend to have students with lower ethical development. These results suggest that student organizations that focus on professionalism and support social movement might support engineering students’ ethical reasoning capability by promoting a shift from an individualistic standpoint towards a more collectivistic standpoint among engineering students. 

The results from this work directly affect student organizations within the studied institutions and beyond. This study involved a diversity of key players in these organizations (e.g. leadership, mentors, members) to open discussion regarding improving engineering ethics behavior. The researchers created a community of practice with the goal to increase the visibility of ethical engineering and knowledge sharing among scholars in the field of ethical STEM. As such, this research promises to move towards educating ethical engineers within and beyond the university.
